title: Trump Today: President says he’ll ‘get rid of’ Nafta if big changes aren’t made
author: Robert Schroeder

thread.title: Trump Today: President says he’ll ‘get rid of’ Nafta if big changes aren’t made
thread.title_full: Trump Today: President says he’ll ‘get rid of’ Nafta if big changes aren’t made - MarketWatch

text:
This column provides a daily update on key presidential actions as well as comments, whether spoken aloud or on Twitter, by President Trump. Like the stock market, the deadline for Trump Today action is 4 p.m. Eastern time, even as we acknowledge that substantive news can and does occur after hours.
President Donald Trump called out the Democrat in Georgia’s special election on Tuesday, signed a “buy American, hire American” executive order during a visit to Wisconsin and threatened to scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement if major changes aren’t made to it.
AIMING AT OSSOFF
• Trump again inserted himself into the special election in Georgia, this time calling out by name Jon Ossoff, the Democrat expected to lead voting in Tuesday’s contest. If rivals keep the former congressional staffer from winning below 50% of the vote, there would be a runoff on June 20 between the top two finishers. That would likely make for a tougher challenge for Ossoff. Trump tweeted twice Tuesday morning, saying the Democrat would be a “disaster” in Congress and urging Republicans to vote. Ossoff has said Trump is “misinformed” about his plans.
Democrat Jon Ossoff would be a disaster in Congress. VERY weak on crime and illegal immigration, bad for jobs and wants higher taxes. Say NO
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) April 18, 2017 Republicans must get out today and VOTE in Georgia 6. Force runoff and easy win! Dem Ossoff will raise your taxes-very bad on crime & 2nd A.
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) April 18, 2017 Getty Images President Donald Trump tours Snap-On Tools alongside Snap-On CEO Nick Pinchuk in Kenosha, Wisc., on Tuesday. ‘BUY AMERICAN’ ORDER
• Trump spoke about his “buy American, hire American” agenda at the Kenosha, Wisc., headquarters of tool-maker Snap-on Inc. SNA, -0.12% He signed an executive order to review high-skilled H-1B visas, which also asked federal agencies to minimize the use of waivers to Buy American policies. The visas should “never, ever be used to replace Americans,” Trump said.
Read: H-1B visa applications drop ahead of Trump move to limit program .
He also said the North American Free Trade Agreement, or NAFTA, should be renegotiated or he will “get rid of it” — a threat that earned mild applause from the audience. He criticized NAFTA over the benefits it gives to the Canadian dairy industry — benefits that would have been curtailed in the Trans Pacific Partnership he dropped in his first week of office.
Read: Why MarketWatch forecaster of the month is racheting back his U.S. growth forecast
